div.p: From John Forrest to the Commissioner of Crown Lands, Western Australia
Colonial Secretary's Office, SDUR/G4/325a, State Archives, Battye Library, Perth.

To proof.
check loc. cit. Is this a copy? It is in the same hand as E. Giles to M, 2 June 1877.
Perth

In accordance with Mr E. Giles wishes as contained in the documents attached,
See E. Giles to M, 2 June 1877 and E. Giles to J. Forrest, 2 June 1877. I have the honor to apply for the 2000 acres on the upper Ferguson and to request that it may be surveyed to meet my wishes and not excactly as applied for, but in such a manner as to take in the best Land, —
I am also to request that if possible the deed issue to Baron von Mueller direct as has been the case with the Timber Company —
I think the colony is fortunate in getting so eminent a man as The Baron von Mueller to be a land owner & most probably ultimately a settler/

div.p:
John Forrest
the file contains a map [SDUR/G4/325] which is a document of 'Application to Purchase a Country [inserted by hand] section of Crown Land in Western Australia.' It has Giles' name on it, is marked '2000 Wellington', shows the blocks of land that make up the 2000 acres applied for on the Ferguson River. The application was received and signed by James Roe for the Commissioner of Crown Land, on 6 September 1877; the sale, at 10/- an acre was approved by Malcolm Fraser, Commissioner of Crown on 19 September and £1000 was received and signed for by […] Collector of Revenue on 19 Sept. It is annotated: 'Authority to re select given by H. E. The Governor' under which was later added: 'Approval cancelled | Malcolm Fraser | 1.3.79'.
There is another letter in the file [SDUR/G4/325D], written by Giles to Fraser, 16 Feb. 1877, saying that he felt that getting 2000 acres compared with Forrest getting 5000 was inequitable against himself. In that letter he refers to a map. A Minute on the letter, dated 10 March 1877 reads: 'Mr Fraser. Tell Mr Giles that I think 2000 acres is as far as I […] be justified in going.' The signature is not easily identifiable. Another minute initialled by Fraser says: 'Mr Giles so informed by note dated 13th March 1877'.

The Hon. Commissioner of Crown Lands
